journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Nanoscale study of cartilage surfaces using atomic force microscopy

article-meta.aff: 1School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, The University of New South Wales, Sydney, NSW, Australia
2School of Pharmacy and Molecular Sciences, James Cook University, Townsville, QLD, Australia
3School of Engineering and Physical Sciences, James Cook University, Townsville, QLD, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Meiling Wang, School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, The University of New South Wales, Sydney, NSW 2052, Australia. Email: meiling.wang@unsw.edu.au

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on orthopaedic navigation technology and biomechanical evaluation for total hip replacement

abstract.p: Articulating cartilage wear plays an important role in cartilage degeneration and osteoarthritis (OA) progression. This study investigated the changes of mechanical properties and surface roughness of sheep cartilages with wear progression at a nanometre scale. Young sheep’s rear legs were subjected to a series of wear tests to generate worn cartilage samples to simulate the OA progression. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) was used to determine the effective indentation modulus and to measure the surface morphology of moist cartilage surfaces. The study has found that the mean effective indentation modulus values of worn cartilages were lower than that of healthy cartilage as the control sample. A medium-to-strong correlation between the effective indentation modulus values and the OA grades has been found. The relation between surface topography and effective indentation modulus values of the cartilage surfaces with OA progression was weakly correlated. The method established in this study can be implemented to investigate the effective indentation modulus values of clinical osteoarthritic cartilages and to assist in the understanding and assessment of OA.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Osteoarthritis (OA) is widely accepted as a ‘wear and tear’-induced disease. The OA process involves various components including articular cartilage (AC), ligaments, periarticular muscle, nerve, bone and meniscus.1 The severity of AC degeneration is most often used to assess OA progression and grade. Healthy cartilage is maintained by a balance of the degradation and regeneration of the cartilage.2 It is thought that if the regeneration and degradation of the cartilage matrix fail to maintain the balance, cartilage degeneration and sequentially OA will occur. This imbalance involves biomechanical and biochemical factors, and has not been completely understood.2 In this process, the cartilage is gradually worn thinner. If the cartilage is worn to expose the subchondral bone, knee replacement is usually required.

Mechanical properties of articulating cartilage surfaces play an important role in articulating mechanics3 as well as OA initiation and progression. Earlier mechanical property studies of cartilage were performed at macro- or micro-length scales in compressive, tensile and indentation testing. Existing compression and indentation tests often used large loads (e.g. 1.8–11.8 N4 and 10 N5) to investigate the mechanical properties of AC. In addition, relatively large tips were utilised with radii of millimetre dimensions (e.g. 0.4 mm,6,7 0.5 mm8 and 1 mm9,10). These approaches using millimetre tips resulted in deformations in the order of hundreds of micrometres (e.g. 40–190 µm10 and 300 µm5).

More specifically, important mechanical properties, such as hardness and stiffness, have been studied.5–7,9,11 For example, a recent study measured hardness, contact stiffness and reduced modulus of cartilage.11 Overall, there is more information relating to the stiffness of cartilage5–7,9 than to its hardness. However, some studies report contradictory outcomes. Although the differentiation of degenerated cartilages was observed,9 the study conducted by Brown et al.12 argued that it was not possible to distinguish between normal and degenerated ACs using indentation stiffness measurements. Young’s modulus of cartilage, an indication of stiffness, was measured.8,13 The unconfined compression test in Korhonen et al.’s13 study revealed that the mean Young’s moduli were 0.80 ± 0.33, 0.57 ± 0.17 and 0.31 ± 0.18 MPa for healthy bovine humeral, patellar and femoral cartilages, respectively. In comparison, an average value of Young’s modulus of healthy human patella cartilage samples was reported to be 0.64 ± 0.30 MPa, measured using unconfined compression testing.8 This study also reported that early degenerated cartilages had a mean modulus value of 0.70 ± 0.62 MPa, and the mean modulus of advanced degenerated cartilages was reduced to be 0.21 ± 0.26 MPa.

Cartilage has a heterogeneous structure and inhomogeneous properties. The pathological changes of the cartilage degeneration start at a nanoscale.14 Atomic force microscopy (AFM) is well suited for investigation of the cartilage degeneration and its location at a sub-micron level, owing to its precise positioning control. It is also well known for its ability to measure contact forces as low as piconewton when using a tip radius of less than 10 nm. AFM has been utilised to study the surface properties of AC14,15 as well as important mechanical properties of cartilages, including friction,16–18 stiffness14 and Young’s modulus.19,20 In Hu et al.’s19 study, Young’s modulus of the fibrocartilage from the articular condyle of rabbit jaw joints was studied using the Hertz model. Research was also carried out to study Young’s modulus of the rabbit proximal radius condyle cartilage using a tip with a radius of curvature of 20 nm.20

In addition to its mechanical properties, surface morphology of AC is equally important to its wear properties and conditions.21–24 Although the surface texture and its changes have been investigated at the micrometre scale,24 there are limited studies on the relationship between changes in the mechanical properties and surface morphology at a nanometre scale and in relation to wear severity. Therefore, the aim of this study is to use AFM to investigate both the effective indentation modulus and surface topography of cartilage surfaces in healthy and degraded conditions. The research outcome will assist in revealing comprehensive wear features of worn cartilages and in further understanding the wear processes.

sec.title: Wear testing
sec.p: Sheep knee joints were selected in this investigation because they were used to investigate wear features and mechanisms with relevance to human knee joints in a number of studies.22–25 In this study, wear tests were conducted on a specially designed wear simulator23 to produce cartilage samples with OA grades described by Kuster et al.26 These OA grades are similar to the Kellgren–Lawrence grading scale and were achieved by controlling the axis impulse applying load, the joint motion frequency and the testing cycle.23

Two healthy, female, approximately 11-month-old sheep, each with a body weight of 35 kg, were used in this study under the approval of the Animal Ethics Committee, James Cook University. Young sheep were chosen to ensure the initial joints were free from wear, diseases and malnourishment. The wear process was simulated by testing the sheep’s rear legs in the wear simulator described by Peng.23 One joint was taken as a control group without being subjected to the wear testing. The other three rear legs were subjected to three separated wear tests to produce the samples with the expected OA grades.

At a fixed axial load of 15 kg and a frequency of 35 Hz of the joint motion, three different wear cycles of 10,000; 17,000 and 37,000 resulted in three OA grades achieved correspondingly. Table 1 summarises the wear testing conditions.23–25 The wear tests were carried out within 12 hrs after slaughtering the sheep so that the material degradation was avoided or minimised. The knee joints were held in the leg capsules of the apparatus during the wear tests. The laboratory conditions (temperature = 21°C, pressure = 1 atm and humidity = 60%) were controlled during the wear tests. Details about the wear tests and the produced OA grades by the wear simulator can be found in Peng’s23 study.

caption.p: Wear test conditions and the corresponding OA grades23–25.

sec.p: Cartilage samples with an approximate size of 12 × 7 × 1.5 mm3 were obtained from the same position across each lateral femoral knee condyle (Figure 1). During the extraction process of the cartilage samples, the knee condyles were moistened with drops of a phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) (pH 7.4) solution to keep the cartilages hydrated. After the sample extraction, the collected samples were immediately submerged into the PBS solution for an hour at 4°C11 and then frozen at −20°C.12,27 Prior to the AFM analysis, the frozen cartilage samples were thawed at 4°C and then brought to room temperature to be prepared for nano-mechanical study. The thawed cartilage samples were glued onto Petri dishes (Sarstedt, Newton, MA, USA) with histoacryl glue (Aesculap AG, Tuttlingen, Germany). To study the mechanical properties and surface morphology of the cartilage surfaces, the superficial layers of the cartilage surfaces were not removed. Thus, the integrity of the collagen network of AC was not disturbed.

caption.p: Cartilage extraction across each lateral femoral knee condyle.

sec.title: AFM instrumentation and probes
sec.p: A TopoMetrix Explorer TMX-2000 (now Veeco Instruments, Plainview, NY, USA) scanning probe microscope (SPM) was used to study the mechanical properties of the cartilage surfaces. This was carried out in the force versus displacement mode. A 130 × 130 µm tripod liquid scanner was used in a range of 9.7 µm in the z direction, which is perpendicular to the cartilage surface plane. Deflection–displacement curves, with each curve consisting of 600 data points, were acquired at rates of translation in a range of 2–5 µm s−1 in the z direction. This was to ensure a minimal drag during measurements. The measurements were carried out in a liquid environment (PBS) with room ambient conditions of 21°C–23°C and 65%–75% relative humidity. The cartilage samples were completely submerged in PBS during the indentation tests so that dehydration was avoided. V-shaped Si3N4 pyramidal tips with a nominal spring constant (kN) of 0.56 N m−1, a nominal tip radius of curvature (Rtip) of 40 nm and a half angle (α) of 22.5° were used to indent the cartilage samples. Silicon wafers used as calibration samples were also indented. Calibration deflection–displacement curves were obtained on clean, flat silicon wafers in the PBS solution prior to the cartilage studies in order to minimise tip contaminations. On each cartilage sample, 10 indentations were made at randomly selected locations.

sec.title: Modulus calculation
sec.p: Figure 2 shows the force–displacement curves of a cartilage sample and a silicon sample as a calibration sample. The deflection sensitivity ds was obtained through conducting a calibration on a clean silicon wafer surface in PBS solution. The cantilever deflection in length (i.e. variable a) was determined using the formula a = dnA/ds, where dnA is the deflection of the raw data and ds is the deflection sensitivity. The force was determined by multiplying the cantilever defection a by the spring constant k of the cantilever, that is, F = ka. Indentation of a cartilage surface was then carried out. The obtained force–displacement data points of the tip indenting the cartilage surface were fit with a cubic spline28 to remove noise in the measurements. The initial contact point was defined as where the linear part of the best fit force–displacement curve in approaching the cartilage surface starts to slope. This point is illustrated as the circled point in Figure 2. A program code was developed to automatically determine the initial contact point. The force at the initial contact point was set to be zero. The indentation depth (d in nanometre) into the cartilage sample was determined by comparing the distance of the displacements of the cartilage and calibration sample at the same force, as shown in Figure 2.

caption.p: Representative force–displacement curves of a cartilage sample (solid blue line) and a silicon sample (dashed purple line) as a calibration sample. The circled point indicates the initial contact point between the sample and the tip.

sec.p: As the indentation depths were within 10% of the entire thickness of the AC samples (generally 1–3 mm), the influence of the substrate was minimal.15 Quantitative evaluation of the force–indentation depth (F–d) data was conducted using the method developed by Sneddon.29 Equation (1) was used to describe the relationship between indentation (d) and applied force F

where C is a factor that depends on the conformational shape assumed by the surface, which is partially related to the indenter shape; E* is the relative Young’s modulus and power n is the exponent that relates to the tip shape. This approach has been recommended to measure the elasticity of biological materials using AFM.30 It was adopted here to study the control and worn cartilage samples. The force–indentation depth (F–d) data for all the samples were processed and then plotted on a logarithmic scale as lnF versus lnd to determine the contact model between the tip and cartilage within 300 nm of indentation depths. Figure 3 shows an example of the force–indentation depth data obtained on the control AC sample. Straight line fits were obtained for indentation depths (<300 nm).

caption.p: (a) A single representative spaced force–indentation (F–d) curve for a control cartilage. (b) Loading force (F) versus indentation depth (d) plotted on a logarithmic scale within the indentation depth of 300 nm. The slope of the straight line can be used to approximate the tip and sample contact geometry within indentation depths from the Sneddon model. R is the correlation coefficient of the experimental data and the linear fit.

sec.p: The selection of the force models for nano-indentation testing is generally based on the geometry of the applied indenter. In this investigation, pyramidal indenters were used. Therefore, the pyramidal force model with a power of 2 was expected to function in the indentation conditions. However, the logarithmic scale of the force–indentation depth data (Figure 3(b)) at the indentation depths of less than 300 nm shows that a power of 1.36 (the slope of the linear regression line) fits the experimental data. This indicates that the parabolic model of a power of 1.5 is more suitable to represent our experimental data than the pyramidal model. Based on the probe shape and materials’ response to the indentation, a parabolic model (i.e. power n = 1.5) was chosen. Further discussion on the suitability of contact models and effects of power n values can be found in section ‘Discussion’. The expression30 adopted in this study is

where Rtip is the tip radius of curvature, F is the total force, d is the indentation depth and E* is the relative Young’s modulus. The effective indentation modulus of cartilage can be calculated using

where Etip is Young’s modulus of the tip; Esample is the effective indentation modulus of the sample and νsample and νtip are Poisson’s ratio of the sample and tip, respectively. Young’s modulus of 150GPa of Si3N4 tip30 is much greater than that of the AC (i.e. Esample << Etip). Therefore, the effective indentation modulus of the AC can be determined by simplifying equation (3) to the following equation

Poisson’s ratio (ν sample) of the AC was taken as 0.5 from human knee condyle AC.5 The modulus results were presented as mean ± standard error (SE) within a 95% confidence level in the result section. Linear regression was conducted in SPSS to quantitatively describe the change in the mean effective indentation modulus with OA grade. The modulus data were used in the linear regression analysis directly, that is, no transformation was performed on the data. The one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and a Tukey’s post hoc test at the 95% confidence level were conducted using the IBM SPSS statistics software. Correlation analysis was conducted using Microsoft Excel.

sec.title: Surface characterisation
sec.p: A Veeco (TopoMetrix Explorer TMX-2000) SPM was used to acquire three-dimensional (3D) images of the cartilage samples hydrated in the PBS solution. The cartilage samples were imaged in a contact mode,31,32 which has been commonly used in AFM imaging cartilage surfaces. The same V-shaped Si3N4 pyramidal tips for studying the mechanical property in section ‘Modulus calculation’ were used in acquiring the AC surface data in this study. The relative set point for imaging was 44 nN, corresponding to deformations of 780–1780 nm, which were dependent on the imaged samples. The image resolution of the scanning was 300 × 300 pixels, and the scanning area was 10 × 10 µm2. The scan rate was approximately 3 Hz. Two images were obtained on each cartilage surface. A standard Gaussian filter with nesting index of 0.5–5 µm was used to extract the average surface roughness (Ra).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The effective indentation modulus values of the indented cartilage surfaces are displayed in Figure 4, which shows the changes in the calculated modulus values at the different loads applied on the surfaces. It is most noticeable that the control cartilage consistently had much higher effective indentation moduli than those of the worn cartilages at the tested loading forces of 10, 20 and 30 nN. The data indicates that the control cartilage surface was stiffer than the worn cartilage samples. A decrease of the mean effective indentation modulus values was observed from the control to the cartilage with OA grade 2. Linear regressions were conducted using SPSS statistical software to quantitatively describe the change of the effective indentation modulus (kilopascal) at loading forces of 10, 20 and 30 nN from the control to OA grade 3. The results are summarised in Table 2. The values of the correlation coefficient (R) indicate that there was a close relationship between the effective indentation modulus and OA severities, particularly from the control sample to OA grade 2 sample. The negative values imply that the modulus decreased with the OA progression. The values of the coefficient of determination (R2>0.6) indicate that more than 60% of the total variation in OA grades can be predicted by the regression model between the effective indentation modulus and OA grades. Then, an increase in the mean effective indentation modulus values was found from the cartilage with OA grade 2 to the cartilage with OA grade 3 in Figure 4. Interestingly, a separate linear regression was conducted on the change of the moduli from the control sample to OA grade 2 sample. Much higher values of the coefficient of determination (R2>0.8) were obtained, revealing that the predictive capability of the regression model was high up to OA grade 2. This result, to be confirmed using human samples, indicates that the effective indentation modulus might be sensitive to OA condition alterations at its early and medium stages.

caption.p: Effective indentation modulus values of the healthy (control) and worn cartilages determined at the loading forces of 10, 20 and 30 nN.
Linear regression results of the values of the effective indentation modulus (kilopascal) at loading forces of 10, 20 and 30 nN and OA grades from the control (OA 0) to OA 2 and 3.

tr.td: At a loading force of 10 nN
At a loading force of 20 nN
At a loading force of 30 nN

fn.label: a
fn.p: Correlation coefficient (R) indicates the strength and the direction of the linear regression model between the measured modulus and OA grade.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Coefficient of determination (R2) gives a measure of the predictive capability of the regression model, that is, the amount of variation in the data actually described by OA grade.

sec.p: Furthermore, Figure 4 also reveals that the values of the effective indentation modulus of the tested cartilages increased with an increment of the loads from 10 to 30 nN, except for the cartilages with OA grade 2. This observation is generally consistent with the finding reported in Franke et al.’s11 study, where the reduced modulus of the hyaline cartilage in PBS solution increased with the applied loading forces. It can be seen from Figure 4 that the modulus increments with the applied load for the worn cartilages were much less than those of the control cartilage. The reasons for the different trends of the cartilages with OA grade 2 are unknown. It might be related to the inhomogeneous property of cartilages under this wear condition and the surface roughness of the cartilages.

The effective indentation modulus results shown in Figure 4 have also indicated a suitable load range for revealing the change in the effective indentation modulus for OA assessment. It can be seen that at the lowest load of 10 nN investigated in this study, the differences among the effective indentation modulus values of the worn samples were marginal, making it difficult to differentiate the cartilages with different OA grades. As the loads increased, the modulus differences became clearer. One-way ANOVA confirmed the observations. At the load of 10 nN, the effective indentation modulus of the healthy cartilage was significantly higher than those of the worn cartilages (p<0.05). However, the modulus differences among the worn cartilages were insignificant (p>0.05). At loads of 20 and 30 nN, the effective indentation moduli were found to be significantly different between the control and OA cartilage samples, while the differences among the three OA grades were not statistically significant. From the results displayed in Figure 4, we propose that a force greater than 20 nN (F≥ 20 nN) needs to be used to indent cartilage samples so that the effective indentation modulus could be used to assess the healthy and osteoarthritic cartilages.

Figure 5 displays the mean modulus values of the cartilage surfaces versus indentation depths. It shows that the healthy cartilage had the maximum mean effective indentation modulus value at the investigated indentation depths. At a certain indentation depth (e.g. 100 nm), the mean effective indentation modulus values decreased from healthy cartilage to OA grade 2 cartilage and then slightly increased from OA grade 2 to OA grade 3. Similar trends were also observed at the indentation depths of 200 and 300 nm.

caption.p: Effective indentation modulus values of the healthy (control) and worn cartilages determined at the indentation depths of 100, 200 and 300 nm.

sec.p: Linear regression was conducted in SPSS statistical software to quantitatively describe the change of the effective indentation modulus (kilopascals) at indentation depths of 100, 200 and 300 nm from the control to OA grade 3. The results are summarised in Table 3. The negative coefficients (R) in Table 3 indicated that as the OA condition progressed, the cartilage surfaces became less stiff. The observed changes in the stiffness confirm that cartilage has inhomogeneous material properties. Decreased stiffness from 100 to 200 nm indentation indicates that the top layer (e.g. 100 nm) may be stiffer than the inner layer (e.g. 200 nm), providing a natural protection to the cartilage. The increase in stiffness from 200 to 300 nm coincided with the finding that the effective indentation modulus showed an increase in value along the depth from superficial zone to calcified zone in the study conducted by Tomkoria et al.20

caption.p: Linear regression results of the values of the effective indentation modulus (kilopascal) at indentation depths of 100, 200 and 300 nm and OA grades from the control (OA 0) to OA 2 and 3.

tr.td: At an indentation depth of 100 nm
At an indentation depth of 200 nm
At an indentation depth of 300 nm

fn.label: a
fn.p: Correlation coefficient (R) indicates the strength and the direction of the linear regression model between the measured modulus and OA grade.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Coefficient of determination (R2) gives a measure of the predictive capability of the regression model, that is, the amount of variation in the data actually described by OA grade.

sec.p: The correlation coefficients of the effective indentation moduli and OA grades from the control to OA grade 3 were −0.772, −0.815 and −0.831, respectively, while the coefficients of determination (R2) were 0.596, 0.664 and 0.690 at the indentation depths of 100, 200 and 300 nm, respectively. These correlation coefficient values imply mild to relatively strong correlations between the indentation moduli and OA grades from the control to OA grade 3 at the indentation depths of 100, 200 and 300 nm. Similar to what was done on the modulus data in Figure 4, a separate linear regression was carried out on the change in the moduli of the control sample to OA grade 2 sample. The coefficients of determination (R2) were 0.828, 0.878 and 0.880 at the indentation depths of 100, 200 and 300 nm, respectively. The results and higher correlation coefficients shown in Table 3 have confirmed the above observation that the modulus can effectively reveal OA condition alterations from control to OA grade 2, but is less sensitive to the change from OA grade 2 to OA grade 3.

Figure 6 shows AFM images of the control and OA-graded worn cartilages with their maximum surface roughness values given in the vertical bars. The images have revealed that the cartilage surfaces were getting rougher from the healthy state to the condition with OA grade 2. Then, the surfaces became smoother when scored with OA grade 3. Figure 7 shows the surface roughness altered with the OA grades in terms of the arithmetic average roughness, Ra. The correlation coefficients between the effective indentation modulus and surface roughness were calculated to be −0.20, −0.18 and −0.15 at the indentation depths of 100, 200 and 300 nm, respectively. These values indicated very weak correlations between these two properties. Furthermore, a correlation coefficient between the surface roughness and OA grades was also conducted to be −0.33. This also revealed a weak correlation between the changes in surface roughness and the progression in OA grades.

caption.p: Representative surface topographies with an area of 10 × 10 µm2 for (a) the healthy (control) cartilage, (b) the cartilage with OA grade 1, (c) the cartilage with OA grade 2 and (d) the cartilage with OA grade 3.
Arithmetic average surface roughness (Ra) of cartilages versus OA grades.

sec.p: The integrity of cartilage collagen networks affects cartilage’s stiffness14 and its surface roughness. Changes in the cartilage collagen networks that underwent the same wear conditions were investigated in a parallel study.25 In that study, histological and immunohistochemical analyses were carried out to observe the changes in the collagen networks of cartilages under wear. The collagen networks stained blue colour using Gomori’s one-step trichrome method are shown in Figure 8. Further details about the histology of the cartilage samples in different wear conditions can be referred to Tian et al.’s25 study. The collagen networks of the control cartilage shown in Figure 8(a) were intact and dense. Compared to the healthy collagen networks, the collagen structure with OA grade 1 shown in Figure 8(b) still looked intact but became a bit loose. A significant difference between the collagen networks with OA grade 2 and the control cartilage was observed in Figure 8(c) in comparison to Figure 8(a). A rough and severely disrupted collagen structure is displayed in Figure 8(c). In the most severe OA grade shown in Figure 8(d), the top collagen networks were observed to be probably worn down to the calcified zone.

caption.p: Micrographs showing cartilage collagen networks stained with Gomori’s trichrome in (a) a healthy (control) cartilage, (b) a cartilage with OA grade 1 corresponding to wear cycles of 10,000, (c) a cartilage with OA grade 2 corresponding to wear cycles of 17,000 and (d) a cartilage with OA grade 3 corresponding to wear cycles of 37,000. Scale bars = 50 µm. Part figures (a) and (d) were provided by Tian.33
Figure 8(c) is reproduced from Ref. 25, copyright © 2011 by Proc IMechE, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine and is reprinted by permission of SAGE.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Changes in mean effective indentation modulus values with wear are considered to be the result from alterations in collagen structures of cartilage surfaces. The disruption of the collagen structure due to wear is believed to contribute to the softening of the cartilage surfaces. The intact and dense collagen network in the healthy sample, revealed in Figure 8(a), was ideal for performing the load-bearing function of cartilages. The slightly loose collagen network shown in Figure 8(b) may have caused the decrease in the mean effective indentation modulus. Rough and severely disrupted collagen structure displayed in Figure 8(c) probably caused a further reduction in the effective indentation modulus, and thus, the cartilage’s load-bearing capability may have been further deteriorated. It was also noticed that the collagen networks parallel to the top surface in the control cartilage were worn off when wear severity reached OA grade 2. This change may also contribute to the changes in the effective indentation modulus and needs to be further investigated. The increase in calcification in the most severe OA grade is believed to contribute to the increased value of the effective indentation modulus at the most severe OA grade.34

During the wear process, the changes in the collagen networks also caused the alterations in the cartilage surface roughness, as shown in Figure 6. Noticeably, the surface roughness deterioration with the increased wear up to OA grade 2 was also confirmed by the microscopic images, as shown in Figure 8(a) to (c). The trend of Ra observed in this study is similar to the trend of the peak height parameter used in Tian et al.’s24 study. The increase in the mean surface roughness values with OA grades (Ra = 51 nm for healthy, 60 nm for OA grade 1 and 75 nm for OA grade 2 cartilages) was mainly due to the disruptions of the collagen networks, as clearly shown in Figure 8(a) to (c). As the intact structures were damaged in the wear process, wear debris was generated at a high wear rate, resulting in a rough cartilage surface. As the wear process reached to the deep zone where calcified cartilages were involved with OA grade 3, the surface became slightly smoother.

Our study has revealed that the alteration of the surface morphology in the wear process was not distinctive enough for OA assessment. The correlation coefficient of −0.33 only shows a weak correlation between the surface roughness and OA grades. A weak correlation was also found between the surface roughness and effective indentation modulus of the tested cartilages. This result needs to be verified in future studies. Three factors may affect the current results. One of the reasons may be resolution. To investigate whether it is a resolution-related issue, the surface morphology of human knee AC samples is being studied using both AFM (at a nanometre scale) and 3D laser imaging systems (at micrometre and millimetre scales). The sampling area can also cause a reliability issue of the surface characterisation. A very small scanning area was used in the present study as it was very time-consuming to image a cartilage surface over a large area using a tiny tip (nanometres). Different imaging areas and their effect on the measurement are being investigated at both micrometre and nanometre scales. The outcomes will be reported in due course. The data size may be the other reason. Significant amounts of samples need to be analysed to establish a reliable conclusion in future studies.

In comparison, the effective indentation modulus and their change can better indicate the evolution of the wear progress corresponding to the OA grades. The correlation coefficients higher than 0.8 at loads of 20 and 30 nN show a strong correlation of the effective indentation modulus and OA grades.

The effect of the contact models and the power (variable n) values on the effective modulus calculation was investigated. Four available models are pyramidal,35 parabolic,30 cylindrical29 and conical30 with a power value, n, of 2, 1.5, 1 and 2, respectively. Table 4 shows the effective indentation moduli of a cartilage at an indentation depth of 300 nm determined using different models. It shows that although the different models yield the different moduli, the general trends of the indentation moduli with the change of OA degrees are consistent. As stated in section ‘Modulus calculation’, the parabolic model was selected based on the slope of the linear regression line of the lnF–lnd curves. The slope value of 1.36 at the indentation depth of 300 nm indicates that the cartilage deformation was close to a parabolic shape. This may be due to the fact that the cartilage surface might not conform to the shape of the pyramidal tip immediately in the investigated indentation depths, which were larger than the nominal tip radius of 40 nm. This model may not be able to generate accurate modulus values due to the complexity of the material property and its response to indentations. However, it is believed that the model is suitable for revealing the change in the modulus for the purpose of this study. For the larger indentations greater than 300 nm, the force model should be determined by the material response to indentation. The conical contact model is probably suitable and is being investigated. However, this model was not used in this article as the indentation depths studied in this project were 300 nm or less. Further study will be needed to obtain the effective indentation modulus values for the indentation depths that are over 300 nm.

caption.p: Effective indentation moduli (kilopascal) calculated using four available models29,30,35 at an indentation depth of 300 nm.

sec.p: Differing from the previous studies,5,10 this study has investigated the mechanical property and surface roughness of the top cartilage surfaces with wear. The strong correlation of the effective indentation modulus and OA grades indicates that the mechanical property of the top layers of cartilage surfaces is of importance in the wear process and assessment. This study also demonstrates that AFM is a powerful tool to study mechanical property and surface morphology of biological samples at the nanometre scale.

We should also state here that the effective indentation modulus in this study was calculated using the Sneddon theory. Sneddon mechanics assumes that the material is elastic and isotropic.30 However, cartilage is viscoelastic and anisotropic. Sneddon mechanics cannot fully characterise the nano-mechanics of cartilage. However, the effective indentation modulus is a good measure of the indentation resistance of cartilage. The effective indentation modulus was used to compare native and proteoglycan-depleted cartilage samples in Han et al.’s36 study. In our study, the effective indentation modulus was related to the cartilage surface degradation due to wear. A further study is being conducted to investigate the changes in the mechanical properties and surface morphology of human cartilage. Alterations of the mechanical properties at an indentation depth of greater than 300 nm will be also studied.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The effective indentation modulus and surface roughness of healthy and worn sheep cartilages have been studied using AFM. The cartilage surfaces showed a softening trend in the initial wear phase and then a stiffening trend in the late wear phase. The measured mechanical property changes have been analysed with the changes in collagen structures and surface morphology. This study has also revealed that cartilage surfaces may have a relatively stiffer top layer compared to the inner surfaces. It has found that the effective indentation modulus of cartilages had a strong correlation with early and mild OA conditions. Although the changes in the surface roughness with the different OA grades have been investigated, this study has not found a strong correlation between the surface topography and the effective indentation modulus. A weak correlation has also been found between the surface roughness and OA grades. Further study will be carried out on human samples to confirm this result.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: a Cantilever deflection in length
d Indentation depth
dnA Deflection of the raw data
ds Deflection sensitivity
k Spring constant of the cantilever
n Exponent that relates to the tip shape
C Factor that depends on the conformational shape assumed by the surface that is partially related to the indenter shape
E* Relative Young’s modulus
Esample Effective indentation modulus of the sample
Etip Young’s modulus of the tip
F Applied force
Fcone Applied force using the conical model
Fcylinder Applied force using the cylindrical model
Fparabola Applied force using the parabolic model
Fpyramid Applied force using the pyramidal model
R Correlation coefficient in linear regression
Ra Arithmetic average roughness
Rtip Tip radius of curvature
R2 Coefficient of determination in linear regression
νsample Poisson’s ratio of the sample
νtip Poisson’s ratio of the tip
α Half angle of the pyramidal tip

ack.p: The authors thank Bart Morris and Brett Rayner for conducting the wear tests and preparing the cartilage samples. The authors also thank Yuan Tian for kindly providing the staining images of cartilages and permitting using the Figure 8 (b).

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The authors would like to thank the Australian Research Council (ARC) for funding the project (DP1093975).

fn.label: Conflict of interest
fn.p: There is no conflict of interest.
